explanation:
OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: This is a macro used with '*sock_token' and '*conn_token'. Its expansion must be inspected to ensure it does not assign to the parameter variables (sock_token/conn_token) via macro text substitution (macros can modify local parameter variables).

OS_IMPL_SET_SOCKET_FLAGS: This macro is invoked with conn_token. Because macros are expanded in the caller scope they could reassign the conn_token parameter (violating the rule). The macro body must be checked to confirm it only dereferences or passes the token and does not modify the pointer parameter itself.

OS_SelectSingle_Impl: This callee is passed sock_token. Although ordinary functions cannot reassign the caller's parameter variable, its prototype/signature is needed to confirm it does not expect or receive the address of the parameter variable (e.g., a pointer-to-pointer) via some indirection. Also inspect whether it is actually a macro or inline that could modify the parameter name.

OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl: Included because OS_IMPL_SET_SOCKET_FLAGS likely expands to a call to this implementation; its prototype/body confirms whether the macro delegates to a function (safe w.r.t. reassigning caller parameter) or if there is a differing mechanism that could modify the parameter variable.

OS_object_token_t: The token type definition is required to determine whether it is itself a pointer type or an aggregate that might interact with macros/functions in ways that could change the visible parameter variable (e.g., if token is a pointer-to-pointer or a macro treats it specially).

OS_impl_file_internal_record_t: The structure type returned by OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET is used (sock_impl, conn_impl). Its definition is needed to confirm that operations on conn_impl->fd and other fields are modifications of the pointee (allowed) and not accidental reassignments of the parameter variables.

OS_SockAddr_t: Definition is needed to confirm that Addr->ActualLength and Addr->AddrData are fields of the object pointed to (allowed to modify) and to check whether any macros/functions operate on the Addr parameter name in a way that would reassign the Addr parameter itself.
